com.disnodeteam.dogecv

Class OpenCVPipeline

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.disnodeteam.dogecv.OpenCVPipeline
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    CameraBridgeViewBase.CvCameraViewListener2
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    CryptoboxDetector, DogeCVDetector, GlyphDetector, JewelDetector 

    public abstract class OpenCVPipeline
extends java.lang.Object
implements CameraBridgeViewBase.CvCameraViewListener2
    Created by guinea on 6/19/17. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Copyright (c) 2018 FTC Team 5484 Enderbots Permission is hereby granted, free of charge, to any person obtaining a copy of this software and associated documentation files (the "Software"), to deal in the Software without restriction, including without limitation the rights to use, copy, modify, merge, publish, distribute, sublicense, and/or sell copies of the Software, and to permit persons to whom the Software is furnished to do so, subject to the following conditions: The above copyright notice and this permission notice shall be included in all copies or substantial portions of the Software. THE SOFTWARE IS PROVIDED "AS IS", WITHOUT WARRANTY OF ANY KIND, EXPRESS OR IMPLIED, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY, FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE AND NONINFRINGEMENT. IN NO EVENT SHALL THE AUTHORS OR COPYRIGHT HOLDERS BE LIABLE FOR ANY CLAIM, DAMAGES OR OTHER LIABILITY, WHETHER IN AN ACTION OF CONTRACT, TORT OR OTHERWISE, ARISING FROM, OUT OF OR IN CONNECTION WITH THE SOFTWARE OR THE USE OR OTHER DEALINGS IN THE SOFTWARE. By downloading, copying, installing or using the software you agree to this license. If you do not agree to this license, do not download, install, copy or use the software. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- This is a base class for an OpenCV pipeline loop. In most cases, one would want to override processFrame() with their own function.

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void disable()
      Detaches the JavaCameraView from the camera and the screen, stopping OpenCV processing.
      void enable()
      Attaches the underlying JavaCameraView to the screen and the camera using the set ViewDisplay to do so, essentially starting OpenCV processing.
      JavaCameraView getCameraView()
      Exposes the underlying JavaCameraView used.
      DrawViewSource getRawView() 
      void init(android.content.Context context, ViewDisplay viewDisplay)
      Initializes the OpenCVPipeline, but implicitly uses the rear camera.

      Initializes the OpenCVPipeline.
      Mat onCameraFrame(CameraBridgeViewBase.CvCameraViewFrame inputFrame)
      The method that calls processFrame(Mat, Mat); there's little reason to override this, if ever.
      void onCameraViewStarted(int width, int height)
      This function is called when the camera is started; overriding this may be useful to set the maximum width and height parameters of an image processing pipeline.
      void onCameraViewStopped()
      Override this function if there should be logic on camera close.
      abstract Mat processFrame(Mat rgba, Mat gray)
      Override this with the main image processing logic.

      • OpenCVPipeline

        public OpenCVPipeline()

    • Method Detail

      • init

        public void init(android.content.Context context,
                 ViewDisplay viewDisplay)
        Initializes the OpenCVPipeline, but implicitly uses the rear camera.
        Parameters:
        context - the application context, usually hardwareMap.appContext
        viewDisplay - the ViewDisplay that will display the underlying JavaCameraView to the screen; in most cases, using CameraViewDisplay.getInstance() as the argument is just fine.

      • init

        public void init(android.content.Context context,
                 ViewDisplay viewDisplay,
                 int cameraIndex,
                 boolean isVuforia)
        Initializes the OpenCVPipeline.
        Parameters:
        context - the application context, usually hardwareMap.appContext
        viewDisplay - the ViewDisplay that will display the underlying JavaCameraView to the screen; in most cases, using CameraViewDisplay.getInstance() as the argument is just fine.
        cameraIndex - The index of the camera to use. On every FTC-legal phone (afaik) 0 is the back camera, and 1 is the front camera.

      • enable

        public void enable()
        Attaches the underlying JavaCameraView to the screen and the camera using the set ViewDisplay to do so, essentially starting OpenCV processing. This function must be called after init().
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if enable() is called before init()

      • disable

        public void disable()
        Detaches the JavaCameraView from the camera and the screen, stopping OpenCV processing. Be careful not to: - disable twice - disable before enabling because dean kamen help you if something bad happens from that

      • getCameraView

        public JavaCameraView getCameraView()
        Exposes the underlying JavaCameraView used. Before init() is called, this is null.
        Returns:
        the JavaCameraView.

      • getRawView

        public DrawViewSource getRawView()

      • onCameraViewStarted

        public void onCameraViewStarted(int width,
                                int height)
        This function is called when the camera is started; overriding this may be useful to set the maximum width and height parameters of an image processing pipeline.
        Specified by:
        onCameraViewStarted in interface CameraBridgeViewBase.CvCameraViewListener2
        Parameters:
        width - - the width of the frames that will be delivered
        height - - the height of the frames that will be delivered

      • onCameraViewStopped

        public void onCameraViewStopped()
        Override this function if there should be logic on camera close.
        Specified by:
        onCameraViewStopped in interface CameraBridgeViewBase.CvCameraViewListener2

      • onCameraFrame

        public Mat onCameraFrame(CameraBridgeViewBase.CvCameraViewFrame inputFrame)
        The method that calls processFrame(Mat, Mat); there's little reason to override this, if ever.
        Specified by:
        onCameraFrame in interface CameraBridgeViewBase.CvCameraViewListener2
        Parameters:
        inputFrame - the input frame given by the internal JavaCameraView
        Returns:
        the result of processFrame(Mat, Mat)

      • processFrame

        public abstract Mat processFrame(Mat rgba,
                                 Mat gray)
        Override this with the main image processing logic. This is run every time the camera recieves a frame.
        Parameters:
        rgba - a Mat that is in RGBA format
        gray - a Mat that is already grayscale
        Returns:
        the Mat that should be displayed to the screen; in most cases one would probably just want to return rgba
